elements.title: Ardwall House (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Ardwall House (pictured) has a garden ornament in the form of an early mediaeval Pictish slab inscribed with a Celtic cross?

elements.title: Henry Janzen (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Henry Janzen was the first coach to lead his team to back-to-back Vanier Cup championships?

elements.title: a Cincinnati TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the main studio of a Cincinnati TV station occupies the one-time gymnasium of a former Black junior high school?

elements.title: Juan José Cabezudo (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Juan José Cabezudo was an openly gay chef and street-food seller in 19th-century Lima?

elements.title: 6th Military Police Group (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the area of responsibility of the 6th Military Police Group includes all of the United States west of the Mississippi River?

elements.title: riots in La Paz (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that when the US government offered Bolivian president Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada US$15 million to help quell riots in La Paz, he responded that he "couldn't even afford to pay for the cigars he smoked"?

elements.title: Emma Hunter (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that telegraph operator Emma Hunter may have been the world's first electronic commuter?

elements.title: Charing Cross Trunk Murder (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a dead woman's knickers helped to solve the Charing Cross Trunk Murder?
